results.headline: Four Countries, Five Bands, One Coast-to-Coast Party
results.summary_short: As a music document and as a labor of unabashed love, the nonfiction feature “Gypsy Caravan” could hardly be better; as a movie, it could stand some improvement.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gypsy Caravan

results.headline: A Difficult Subject and a Delicate Balance
results.summary_short: The documentary “Unborn in the USA” is billed as a rigorously objective look at the anti-abortion movement, and that’s accurate — but only to a point.
results.display_title: Unborn in the USA: Inside the War on Abortion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unborn in the USA: Inside the War on Abortion

results.headline: All in the Genes
results.summary_short: Eartha Kitt stands out in the otherwise uneventful romantic comedy,  “And Then Came Love.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of And Then Came Love

results.headline: Armageddon Comes Knocking
results.summary_short: “Rise of the Silver Surfer” is an existentially and aesthetically unnecessary sequel to the equally irrelevant if depressingly successful “Fantastic Four.”
results.display_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer

results.headline: The Comedy of Capitalism
results.summary_short: In the documentary “Czech Dream,” two students at the Prague Film Academy use state money to stage an elaborate consumer hoax.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Czech Dream

results.headline: Fighting Words
results.summary_short: “Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict” methodically traces the battle over turf from its biblical origins to the fragile present.
results.display_title: Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blood and Tears: The Arab-Israeli Conflict

results.headline: A Family Struggling to Heal
results.summary_short: The documentary “Beyond Hatred” is an example of a film whose style doesn’t merely suit its story but amplifies its meanings.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beyond Hatred

results.headline: Loser, Loser Burning Bright in the Grim Helsinki Night
results.summary_short: A mood of cosmic desolation seeps like late autumn sunlight filtered through clouds in Aki Kaurismaki’s “Lights in the Dusk.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lights in the Dusk

results.headline: A Cult Swallows Up Teenagers for a Strange Rental Business
results.summary_short: One of the most ambitious tonal mash-ups in memory, “Noriko’s Dinner Table” is a domestic comedy, a bloody psychological thriller and a comment on the fragility of identity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Noriko's Dinner Table

results.headline: They Always Come Out Ahead; Bet on It
results.summary_short: With “Ocean’s Thirteen,” the gang’s all here, looking fighting trim and Hollywood beautiful, at your disposable pleasure.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ocean's 13

results.headline: A French Songbird’s Life, in Chronological Disorder
results.summary_short: “La Vie en Rose” shows that we Americans don’t have a monopoly on singers and composers who emerge from personal troubles and win the hearts of millions.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of La Vie En Rose

results.headline: Paying the Price on Both Ends of a Hangman’s Rope
results.summary_short: In “Pierrepoint — The Last Hangman” Timothy Spall sinks his teeth into one of the juiciest roles of his career.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Pierrepoint: The Last Hangman

results.headline: The Joys of Teaching? Get Lost, Mr. Chips
results.summary_short: The loose-jointed ensemble comedy “Chalk” follows three teachers and one administrator over nine months.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chalk

results.headline: For a Cinematic Object of Desire, a Second Act
results.summary_short: Having tapped into reserves of great love or shocking hubris, the Portuguese filmmaker Manoel de Oliveira revisits Luis Buñuel’s classic with “Belle Toujours.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Belle Toujours

results.headline: Birds on Boards
results.summary_short: This addition to the kiddie canon follows a young Rockhopper penguin with surfing in his blood and dreams of greatness in his head.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Surf's Up

results.headline: A Rocker’s Climb From Despair
results.summary_short: “You’re Gonna Miss Me” follows Roky Erickson, the lead singer of the 13th Floor Elevators and maybe the most influential 1960s pop star that most folks haven’t heard of.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You're Gonna Miss Me

results.headline: The Brutal Struggle for Survival
results.summary_short: The events recounted in the World War II drama “Miriam” are horrific, and the story behind it is moving. Unfortunately, the finished product feels like exploitation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Miriam

results.headline: Inside the Torture Factory
results.summary_short: Eli Roth’s “Hostel: Part II” may sport glossier production values than the first in the series, but its driving motivation remains just as low.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hostel: Part II

results.headline: A Romanian Town Slouches Toward Revolution and Beyond
results.summary_short: Though it is modest, almost anecdotal, in scale, “12:08 East of Bucharest” is also characterized by a precise and sneaky formal wit.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 12:08 East of Bucharest

results.headline: Commuter Ticket to Hades: A Ghost Haunts the Railroad
results.summary_short: In Takeshi Furusawa’s “Ghost Train,” a group of high school students tries to unravel a mystery that leads the teenagers into the bowels of their city.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Train
